content: I've tested your DFS code and my BFS code on some of the cases. For both solutions, Tests/Validators 16 to 18 run much faster than Tests/Validators 12 and 13. It seems the cases should have been ordered differently, but if you'd prefer to keep the current order (especially if there are other reasons for the order), that's fine. We should just keep in mind that execution time is one of the factors to consider when deciding case order in future contributions. You may want to check again the case order in "Snowflakes", for example.

Update Log:
Updated the header "In the grid:" to "Grid Legend:"

Hello, this puzzle is very nice.

What I am missing while I am solving it is a description of the optimal steps for the first example.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: YAWN! This puzzle is so fun I'm too tired to make a report. Enjoy your acceptance!

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's a funny pathfinding puzzle. 
Coder needs to be careful to stick to the statement precisely when implementing handling the ghosts.

validator 3 and validator 7 are a bit too different from their ide test case counterparts. I suggest to make test cases and validators to test the same aspect of a solution. 
Pls keep validator 3 because it is a good extreme edge case, just make a similar ide test for it.

Maybe you could give a hint in the constraint sections about the max number of fruits in the map. 
I checked a few test cases and wrongly assumed there are <64 fruits, and used an int64 as bitmap to track which fruit was eaten. My first solution then failed validator 3 and two others because there are over 64 fruits...

I have not looked at any test cases yet. In the statement, you say:

"Pac-Man MUST avoid being eaten."

Why? What happens if he does get eaten?

I assume his energy goes to zero. Does he get to keep his score? My guess is that he does get to keep his score, but the game is over. If that is true, then... Pac-Man MUST  maximize his score. Getting eaten has consequences to his energy and his ability to continue, but it is not something Pac-Man must not let happen, right?

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Wow, this one was a bit harder than I though :) Nicely polished and complete puzzle. The energy-score pair makes memoization/edge cutting not exactly trivial. Good work!

(Solved using recursive backtracking in Kotlin)

Nice puzzle (still need to solve some testcases)

Recommendations:
- First constraint: *swap w and h* - to keep it in same order as in Input Line 1
- Tags: consider adding *memoization and recursion*. But still... 5 tags is maybe too much 

I'll approve after solving it completely
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

i will try tomorrow to create a code and see what happen (i didn't see the code solution) i hope this get approved

Do the ghosts not move? My initial thought was this should be a game instead of a puzzle if so. But then if they don't move, in what sense do they "wrap around"? Only if they are placed at the edge of the map, covering a single square on the other side? If I've worked it out correctly, it makes sense, but not immediately obvious.

Goal
* Last paragraph: Please change "fruits points" to "fruit's points".

Input
* The order is [[w]] then [[h]] instead of [[h]] then [[w]].

* [[energy]] is missing.

Cases
* Complex 1 (test): The last line of the grid is 1 character short.

* Complex 3 (test): There are two "Pac-Man"s in the grid.

* Validator 13: There are two "Pac-Man"s in the grid.

* "No Energy" (test) and Validator 5 are too different. Please split the cases into two pairs: one pair featuring Pac-Man with 0 energy on a non-empty grid, one pair featuring Pac-Man with positive energy on an empty grid (i.e. the grid contains just Pac-Man and empty space).

* "No Moves" (test) and Validator 6: In the test, Pac-Man cannot move because of barriers. In the validator, Pac-Man cannot move because of ghosts. Please revise both cases so that each case features both, i.e. two sides of Pac-Man are blocked by barriers and the other two sides are essentially blocked by ghosts.

* 80x80 grids seem to be a waste because of the [[energy]] limit of 25, which means the maximum accessible area of Pac-Man is only 50x50. Suggest to either reduce the maximum grid size (say 60x60) and/or increase the [[energy]] limit if possible.

Thanks.
Updated, thanks! Not sure how I missed the missing input and extra Pac-Mans...
You are correct! I've reworded so hopefully it is more clear.

Thanks ðŸ™‚

Swapped them around, thanks for pointing that out.
Added the tags, I did have them originally but swapped them out when I was considering changing the testcases - But they're probably worth adding to give hints about reducing the number searches.

My understanding is that if Pac-Man gets eaten it cannot continue its journey.
It does not matter if  you assume if it can keep its score or not,  the puzzle solution is the same. This is because he could have just go back and forth till the energy runs out between the last 2 valid positions before where it was eaten to avoid eating.
Also, a Medium puzzle shouldn't require extensive optimisation to solve. If its success rate remains below 50% over time (say, after a year), it may be a good candidate to upgrade to Hard.

I have reorderd the cases placing the longer 12 and 13 at the end.

I generally do get the rating wrong so I'll leave it for now then.

I'll also mention that the also medium rating 'Connect the Colours - Part 1' is currently on 44.44% however part 1 if moved up rating would then be on the same rating as part 2 (and we know part 2 is harder) - What would you suggest in that case? Making the test cases slightly easier or match the rating of part 2?

It's natural for Part 2 of a two-part puzzle to have a higher success rate, since typically only those who have completed Part 1 will proceed to Part 2.

Additionally, as mentioned earlier, we should observe the data over a longer period. The current bases (the total number of people who have started each puzzle) are still quite small (fewer than 100 for all three). A larger population size will provide a more reliable indicator of the puzzles' difficulty levels.

Hope this clarifies! ðŸ™‚

What if a fruit is right next to a ghost? What happens first if Pac-Man moves into the fruit location? Does Pac-man eat the fruit before the ghost eats Pac-Man or does the ghost eat Pac-Man before Pac-Man harvests the points for the fruit? The former scenario results in a better score than the latter.

You are right, the author should clarify this in the statement. I also made some suggestions in separate comments. 
(I  just solved the puzzle and ready to approve after these concerns are handled.)
Assuming Pac-Man gets to eat the fruit before a ghost eats the Pac-Man,I think it would be possible to have a test case where Pac-Man must sacrifice his life to get the highest score.

Updated the statement and the cases referenced above.

I like the idea of Pac-Man staying alive - To simpify the statement I've said score is 0 if he's eaten rather than saying he would be eaten before he can eat the fruit.

Let me know if you notice anything else ^^ Thanks!

No worries ðŸ™‚

I've just had another idea for you to consider: in the new test/validator, the grid is small enough and/or the energy level is high enough that Pac-Man can move through all four edges a few times. The aim is to test whether the player's code correctly counts each fruit item once only.

This idea also leads me to another question: do the current cases cover all types of wrap-around movements (i.e. across all four edges)?

Could you expand on your first point? I'm slightly confused on the meaning.
My interpretation is you're referring to a new/related puzzle with something like:
* #*   4#5 <= Valid   ##* <= Invalid as one fruit is unvisited
) # *   7#6                  . # .
###   ###                 ###
P # .   P#1                 P#*
.  # *  3#2                 *#*
Output potentials: Number of ways to visit every fruit once / boolean - is it possible? / number of unvisited fruits etc. Let me know if I'm way off though...

The cases do test all wrap-arounds with the most involving 3 wraps to solve. Examples: Validator 8 tests both vertical wraps, Validator 13 and 14 contains left and right wraps respectively. The test and validators pairs don't check the exact same wraps (e.g. Complex 3 test left=>Right and bottom=>top while it's validator checks right=>left and bottom=>top). If they need to match exactly I can change and/or add a case involving all 4 wraps.

(1)
I don't mean a new puzzle ðŸ˜› I just mean a new case like this:

https://imgur.com/DEN3mBy

Pac-Man can wrap around more than once (say initial [[energy]] = 25), and the player will output a wrong answer if they do not keep track of which fruits have been eaten.

(2)
I think the minimum I would like to see is that all wraps are covered in visible tests, and all wraps are covered in invisible validators. If that's not the case right now, you may achieve that minimum by adding the case in (1) above with a similar validator (or as you said, a case involving all 4 wraps).

Hope this clarifies.

Gotcha!(maybe...) Most test/validators requires the player to have kept track of visited/eaten fruit and only count it once. If this wasn't the case, the solution would only need to find the nearest instances of each type of fruit, traverse to each, then move on and off to accumulate score then select the max score between them. If you're referring to a case where ALL the fruit is eaten and ensure that it's only counted once, then no, there is no test case currently for this.

A few thoughts have come to mind based on your example:
Given a small grid with large energy, it's possible to navigate the entire grid with and without the use of wrapping. Both methods provide the same score of 34. However, the minimum energy used for non-wrap routes is 23 but the minimum energy used for a wrapping route is 21. Taking this into account, the 'best' solution is the one with the highest score and with the most energy remaining - tired Pac-Man doesn't want to move if he doesn't get any score out of it :( Additionally, there are a total of 95 routes that provide 34 as an answer. These two pieces of information could be used for additional outputs or do you think it's unnecessary?

Validators - I'll alter to ensure that all wraps are in visible tests and their corresponding validators check the same wraps. Also, I will add your example case of a small grid with large energy including 4 wraps.

(1)
Your analysis is indeed correct! And I think it'll be good to add a pair of cases where ALL the fruit is eaten and the player must ensure that each is counted once only.

(2)
If in most cases Pac-Man will use up all the initial energy, then it doesn't seem necessary to request the additional output because it'll be merely repetition. (An alternative is to request the output of minimum energy used only when Pac-Man can eat all the fruit without consuming all the initial energy, but it may complicate things and I personally don't prefer that. But it's up to you.)

(3)
OK! Just let me know when you've updated the cases, and I'll review them again.

Thanks!

Updated tests!

Test 12 / Validator 12 => Small grid, high energy, All fruit eaten.
Test 13 / Validator 13 => All 4 Wraps.
Test 15 / Validator 15 => L-R wrap and T-B wrap.
Test 16 / Validator 16 => R-L wrap and B-T wrap.
All looks good to me, except that Pac-Man has gone missing in Validator 12! ðŸ˜†
Got him out of bed and he's now there! Thanks for the help!
